utterances: What do these little pieces mean?
Yeah.
Took us a while to figure us out.
What you see is a lot of stuff that is white.
White is the color of ash of death and it leads the spirit and the spirit can be found following it or caught by it on its way home to the sea, the original place of birth of all of humanity.
It's called a cash because the trinkets and charms are bundled together and then hidden.
It looks just like the ones used in West African spiritual traditions, but these are made with local materials, like those peach pits.
The cache was meant to trap spirits and use them for healing or protection, Leone says.
Rob Sachs strapped himself in and rode up with window washer Allejandro Alvez(ph).
If for some reason investors began to see U.S.
assets as less attractive, they'd buy a lot less.
The dollar would fall.
The government would have to pay more to borrow.
And that hasn't happened, but Celeste Drake of the AFL-CIO says the trade deficit is a sign that something's seriously out of whack with the economy.
Drake says economists have been making promises about trade for years.
They've said foreign markets would open up and U.S.
companies would begin exporting more.
Instead, the trade deficit has only gotten bigger.
The U.S.
is running the largest and most sustained trade deficit ever recorded in history.
Meanwhile, as Americans buy more products overseas, it's eliminated jobs in the U.S., and wages for many U.S.
workers have been stagnant or worse.
Drake says, all this suggests that the country needs to pay more attention to the trade deficit.
Certainly, it is a measurement that something's really quite out of balance with the American economy, and we should stop ignoring it.
President Trump agrees, and he's made clear he's willing to risk a trade war to change the system.
But in the process, he'll have to contend with a consumer culture that loves to buy things and enjoys the benefits that trade provides.
Jim Zarroli, NPR News, New York.
Authorities don't yet say what group may have tried to carry this out, but perhaps we can infer something from how complicated it would be to attack.
We're joined by Professor Paul Pillar, who teaches at Georgetown University in Washington in the security studies program.
He was with the CIA for more than 20 years.
Professor Pillar, welcome.
Nice to be with you, Alex.
Let's go through this plot as described by authorities.
Attacks on as many as 10 planes, liquid bombs smuggled on board by terrorist passengers, perhaps different components carried by different passengers.
From what we've heard so far, the bombs all on planes from London to the U.S., all to explode within a short time of each other.
It actually sounds fairly complicated to me.
First of all, go back a little bit in history, because this particular methodology has a clear precedent.

It was the very same, almost the exact same, method that was attempted by Ramzi Yousef, the leader of the World Trade Center bombing in 1993, who after he fled after that incident had this plot to blow up about a dozen U.S.
airliners over the Pacific in the Far East.
This was in 1994 and '95.
That plot got foiled when, as they were mixing their materials - they were assembling them in an apartment in Manila - they accidentally set off a fire, and the fire department discovered them.
If you were running this, just in practical operational terms, what would you have to consider?
What kinds of things do you have to think about?

The security countermeasures, and we know from going back to the Yousef experience and the interrogations of him after the earlier plot, he was highly conscience of this, thinking about what sorts of materials could be sneaked past security, and of course back in those days, the aviation security checkpoints were much less rigorous than what we have today.
That's the first thing you have to consider.
And then you have to consider on-flight security measures, sky marshals, and that sort of thing.

Wouldn't you have to teach the people who were going to carry this out how to do it, that is, how to get these bomb components safely on board and then put them together on board and then put them together in such a way that they'd actually go off?

On the sheer mechanics of putting an explosive together, and I'm not an engineer or a technical expert, but my understanding of the sorts of materials that could be used, they are not that hard to put together to combine in a way that would cause at least a small explosion or a large fire.

And we should remember that any kind of thing going bang at 30,000 feet in a thin-skinned aircraft can be much more destructive, to the point of being catastrophic, than it would be on the ground, where it might make a relatively small amount of damage.
How about communication, maintaining discipline, and information, that kind of thing?
Would cell phones be safe, or would they have to have something better than that?

They generally are highly conscious of operational security, well aware of the well-publicized communications-intercept capabilities of the authorities in the United States, Britain, and elsewhere, keeping most of their communications, or to the largest extent possible, face to face.

And another technique that they have used in the past, particularly overseas, is with the use of pre-paid chips or cards that don't associate a particular cell-phone number with any one address or any one individual.
So they use all these techniques to try to minimize their vulnerability.
How about fake IDs?
Wouldn't it be risky for potential bombers to use their real names when boarding planes, because you wouldn't know if you might be on a watch list, so you'd have to get fake IDs for 20 people.
We've had unfortunate incidents where, say, a supply of blank passports had been stolen from the embassy of a particular country somewhere, and they enter the black market.
But there again, fake identification is not absolutely essential.
As we saw to our horror in the investigation of 9-11, we had some of those perpetrators operating under their real name.
I would not see that as an insuperable barrier to even a modestly organized organization, but it's certainly one of the major things that they would have to plan for and prepare for.

But you know, isn't there a kind of difference in scale if you're talking about someone who organizes to buy subway tickets and someone who organizes to buy transatlantic airplane tickets and maybe for multiple trips?
There's talk about test runs, that sort of thing.
People who are going to maybe acquire fake IDs, bomb components - I mean it just seems much more grand, if you will.
Remember after 9-11 how many times you head, oh, there must have been a state security service behind this.
Well, there wasn't.
Yes, you need a little more money, of course, to buy airplane tickets and to buy train or transit or bus tickets.

But as far as coordinating schedules and things like that, not only are we all quite experienced with using cell phones, but you or I could get online and research the airline schedules and probably, in pretty short order, come up with our own list of simultaneous flights that would make tempting terrorist targets for an operation like this.
The spirit has to do what is invoked, and that's quite different from either Protestant or Catholic Christianity.
It means that the spirits, like the holy spirit, are far more active in people's lives than they would be in the normal European interpretation.
Later caches found in other Annapolis buildings show the spiritual practices mixing with Christianity.
There's one intriguing piece.
It's a tiny little charm the size of a ladybug, a hand holding a ring.
Leone calls it a fist charm and says it's evidence that the early slaves were practicing the Muslim religion here too.
And therefore in 18th and 19th century Annapolis there are other religions beyond Christianity.
So, despite how slave masters may have tried, they could not break the culture of the Africans that were brought here.
Maybe they hid it but they kept putting these things in these caches, they kept speaking to their spirits.
You can tell that.
We could not only tell that, through archaeology we can actually use artifacts to understand the wholeness and the complexity of people's lives.
So our contribution to Annapolis is an understanding that this is an African city with African traditions alive as well as the European city.
Dr.
Leone, thank you so much for joining me here.
Entirely my pleasure.
Mark Leone is an archaeology professor at the University of Maryland.
He's also the head of the Archaeology in Annapolis Project.
A military and diplomatic crisis is deepening in South America, it involves Colombia, Ecuador - its neighbor to the southwest - and Venezuela, its neighbor to the northeast.
On Saturday, Colombian troops launched a raid on rebel camps inside Ecuador.
They killed 17 rebels including the second-ranking commander of the Marxist group, the FARC.
In response, both Ecuador and Venezuela have severed diplomatic ties with Colombia, and both countries have sent troops to their borders.
Chris Kraul of the Los Angeles Times is following the story from the Colombian capital, Bogota.
And Mr. Kraul, explain please how the Colombian president, Alvaro Uribe is justifying this raid on Saturday into Ecuador.
Well, initially, this was a Colombian operation that began on Colombian territory, but then spilled over into Ecuador.
Uribe said the units that were looking for this rebel, Raul Reyes, received fire from (unintelligible) south of the borders.
So in hot pursuit, Colombian troops and aircraft crossed over the line and killed this rebel leader.
So the initial explanation and - the official explanation that Colombia has held to has been that it's - the situation is hot pursuit.
And does Ecuador buy that?
No.

Ecuador sent a delegation to inspect the site and there were still victims there on the scene when they arrived Saturday, and found that - according to the Ecuadorian government - many of them seem to be in their pajamas.
So the Ecuadorians reaction was, this could not have been hot pursuit.
This is a preplanned operation.
Colombia has also claimed that Ecuador has been helping these FARC guerillas - meeting with them, working out ways to accommodate them inside Ecuadorian territory.
Right.
That's one of the revelations that has emerged since this operation.
They recovered three laptops that this rebel leader had.

And according to Colombian police, they demonstrate that there were ongoing talks, relations between the rebels and the Ecuadorian government; that the interior minister, Gustavo Larrea, had met with Reyes a time or two.
Apparently, the laptops are just a treasure trove of details in how the FARC managed external relations.
One of the revelations is that it received $300 million from Hugo Chavez.
Which brings us to Venezuela.
As we said, Ecuador has sent troops to the border.
And on the other side of Colombia, Venezuela has, too.
Why is Venezuela involved?
Well, the people in Venezuela are asking that question - why is Hugo Chavez mobilizing troops?
He says he's doing it to defend against the possible incursion such as the one that the Colombian military forces carried out in Ecuador.
But his opponents in Venezuela say it's merely to distract the attention of Venezuelans who are increasingly suffering from boo scares from this high crime and the lack of basic services.
Do you think there's the real threat of military action on either one of these borders?
I think the chances are smaller at this point.
The three countries have enjoyed pretty good relations for decades, centuries.
So the idea that there could be a real shooting war is not something people want to contemplate.
And at this point, it seems a very remote possibility, but as days go on we'll have to watch.
Let's talk about some of the allegiances here.
President Bush today came out and said that the U.S.
will stand by the Colombian president, President Uribe.
He criticized what he called provocative maneuvers by the president of Venezuela, Hugo Chavez.
Where do all these players line up?
Well, Bush may find himself alone.
Sovereignty is a hot issue in South America.
They have are borders - it's all over the place.
So it's an issue that leaders care about and know they have to uphold in public.
So - and for that reason, most countries have come down on the side of Ecuador in this dispute.
Okay.
Chris Kraul, thanks very much for talking with us.
Thank you.
Chris Kraul with the Los Angeles Times, speaking with us from Bogota.
